title: 114_hr5974
content: The Act may be cited as the "Coptic Churches Accountability Act". Congress finds that in August 2013, Islamist-led mobs burned and destroyed Christian properties in Egypt after the government led by the Muslim Brotherhood was removed. The succeeding government, under President Sisi, announced that the army would rebuild the damaged churches at government expense. President Sisi has shown support for the Coptic Christian community by attending Christmas liturgies and acknowledging their historical and national role. In January 2015, President Sisi made an appearance at a Coptic Christian Christmas liturgy. In January 2016, he promised to restore all churches damaged in the August 2013 violence. The Egyptian military and private citizens have restored many buildings, but 29 remain unrepaired as of September 2016. In August 2013, sectarian violence damaged churches and Christian buildings. Private citizens restored 23 buildings, but 29 remain unrepaired as of September 6, 2016. Egypt passed a law in August 2016 imposing burdens on church construction. Government approval for building or repairing churches has led to violence against Christians. In El-`Our, Minya, villagers protested the building of a new church honoring Christians beheaded by Da'esh militants in Libya in February 2015. President Sisi approved the construction in response to calls by Coptic Orthodox Church leaders. In February 2015, President Sisi approved the construction of a new church in response to calls by Coptic Orthodox Church leaders. Protestors armed with Molotov cocktails besieged the existing village church, set fire to a Christian-owned vehicle, and threw bricks at another Christian's house. Egyptian government officials hold informal reconciliation sessions to address sectarian violence, but outcomes are often unfavorable to religious minorities. Coptic Christians have been in Egypt for over 2,000 years, with St. Mark bringing Christianity to the country. The Coptic Christians, indigenous to Egypt for over 2,000 years, face unfavorable outcomes in reconciliation sessions led by Egyptian government officials. The largest Christian community in the Middle East, the Coptic Church, relies on US diplomatic leadership for international protection of religious minorities. The International Religious Freedom Act of 1998 emphasizes the promotion of religious freedom as a fundamental right essential for democracy and individual liberty. The International Religious Freedom Act of 1998 emphasizes the promotion of religious freedom as a priority for the United States in its engagement with other countries. SEC. 3. REPORT. The Secretary of State must provide a report on the progress of restoring Christian religious properties in Egypt, including discussions with Egyptian officials, permits issued for church construction, and an assessment of Egyptian laws and policies. The Secretary of State must report on the restoration or repair of Christian religious properties in Egypt, including permits issued for church construction and an assessment of Egyptian laws and policies regarding Christian churches. The Secretary of State must report on the restoration or repair of Christian religious properties in Egypt, including permits issued for church construction and an assessment of Egyptian laws and policies regarding Christian churches. Each Report on International Religious Freedom must include a summary of information and a list of Christian religious properties destroyed during sectarian violence in August 2013.
